body.title: Orb-Shaped UFO Filmed On Tarmac At British Airport Sparks Intense Speculation
body.description: Video and images of an orb-shaped UFO allegedly taken by a co-pilot on a runway at Manchester Airport in Great Britain have ...
body.article_content:
iStockphoto

Video and images of an orb-shaped UFO allegedly taken by a co-pilot on a runway at Manchester Airport in Great Britain have led to many unanswered questions. The sighting reportedly occurred this past June, but was just shared last week. However, the person who originally shared the material has disappeared from the internet.

The anonymous source, who went by the pseudonym “CaptainBiggalow” on X (Twitter), claimed to be an airline pilot who received the video and images from a colleague. He also claimed that after the UFO sighting, airport security was dispatched to investigate the UFO sighting.

“However, he said, seemingly upon realizing it had been spotted, the object departed the scene with a sudden vertical ascent,” reporter Tim Binnall of Coast to Coast AM wrote. “Adding another layer of mystery to the curious case, the CaptainBiggalow account shut down shortly after the post caught the attention of UFO enthusiasts online and spawned a dizzying amount of discussion on Reddit.”

Over on Reddit, in the post discussing the strange UFO sighting, someone explained, “OP deleted his account on X and Reddit. I assume probably got some hate from somewhere. It’s a shame this is the world we live in. Luckily u/Own-Resolution-8476 made contact and got the OP’s original files, and made an X post as well.”

“Spoke to @captainbiggalow & got photos they received from their colleges at Manchester airport,” that person wrote on X. “No metadata could be recovered, ELA good. Timeline clarified, object seen on ground (1) (2), reported to tower, ops vehicle investigates (3), orb shoots up and video taken (4).”

Spoke to @captainbiggalow & got photos they received from their colleges at Manchester airport. No metadata could be recovered, ELA good. Timeline clarified, object seen on ground (1) (2), reported to tower, ops vehicle investigates (3), orb shoots up and video taken (4). pic.twitter.com/HqRlsf10Cq — PNW MPA (@PNWMPA) November 27, 2024

The original source of the images and video also wrote before deleting their Reddit account, “Hello everyone. The link to this thread was posted on the X thread. I thought I’d join in the conversation to clarify some points of discussion.

“Firstly my name is not Biggalow. I wont be revealing my true identity because I would like to remain anonymous. The last thing I want is my name or the first officers plastered all over the internet for the world to see. Please be respectful that we are professionals and like to keep our heads down and our noses clean. If the meta data reveals any personal details please do not post them.

“That being said I created the x account to share the photos video with the world as I believe they need to be seen. I have been an airline pilot for a UK operator for several decades and we know what is normal and what isn’t. The photos and video were taken by a colleague and as such I can only relay what was told to me. But rest assured we know what we are looking at in the skies. This is not a balloon or a drone and has been a hot topic of conversation in our community for quite a while.”

What is it? And is it real? We may never know. But we do know that during the first public briefing held by a NASA group that was formed to study UFOs reported a large number of unexplained metallic orbs have been spotted at high altitudes around the world.

“This is a typical example of the thing that we see most of. We see these all over the world and we see these making very interesting apparent maneuvers,” said Dr. Sean Kirkpatrick, then the director of the U.S. Department of Defense’s All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office (AARO).

body.title: Chinese Man Trapped In Well For 3 Days As Villagers Mistake His Cries For Ghost Sounds
body.description: It wasn't until police dispatched rescue personnel to the forest that they heard a voice responding to their calls.
body.article_content:
In a bizarre incident near the Thailand-Myanmar border, a Chinese man was trapped in an abandoned well for three days. Villagers had heard strange cries coming from a nearby forest, but mistook them for ghostly sounds, according to Thai media reports. It wasn't until police dispatched rescue personnel to the forest that they heard a voice responding to their calls. The crew located the source of the voice and found 22-year-old Liu Chuanyi at the bottom of a 12-metre-deep well, Independent reported. The rescue operation lasted 30 minutes.

Mr Chuanyi was found in a weakened state and had sustained serious injuries, including a fractured wrist, cerebral concussion, and bruises, after being trapped without food or water for three days and nights. He was rescued and taken to the hospital for medical attention.

According to Mr Chuanyi, he strategically shouted for help once every hour, conserving his energy during his three-day ordeal. Meanwhile, nearby villagers reported hearing strange cries, which they attributed to paranormal activity. As a result, they avoided venturing outside after dark and didn't investigate the noise further.

Authorities believe that Mr. Liu accidentally fell into the well while attempting to navigate his way out of the forest. The circumstances surrounding Mr Liu's presence at the Thailand-Myanmar border remain a mystery, and authorities have reached out to the immigration department to investigate how he ended up in the area. In the meantime, local authorities are taking proactive measures to prevent similar incidents by sealing the well with a cover, ensuring the area is safer for everyone.

The incident has sparked widespread attention on Chinese social media, with many users sharing and discussing the harrowing story.

One user wrote, "A Chinese man shouting for help in the middle of nowhere? Of course, the locals can't understand the language and might think it was a wizard uttering spells."

Another commented, "Kudos to his strength and stamina. Struggling for three days and nights but still yelling; this guy is truly impressive."

body.title: My husband and I went to New Orleans in December. The cooler weather and holiday vibes made it unforgettable.
body.description: Here's how to spend a fun weekend in New Orleans during the holidays. We share places to stay, where to eat, and things to do ...
body.article_content:
A few years ago, my husband and I visited New Orleans for the first time in December. This trip was so memorable that New Orleans became one of my favorite cities in the US. There’s something alluring about its history, supernatural lore, music, and food. Combine all this with Christmas lights, Réveillon multi-course holiday dinners, and cooler weather; December is the best time to visit.

You can’t beat the weather

Ashlee eating Rockefeller oysters at Gallier’s / Roosevelt Hotel lobby

We arrived at Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport. The airport was smaller than I imagined and easy to navigate. Rolling our carry-ons, we followed the signs toward the rideshares. Once we stepped outside the terminal, a cool but humid breeze hit my skin, and I was surprised. I thought it would be warmer outside.

This is when I learned that you can’t beat the cooler weather this time of year in the South along the Gulf. It is typically in the mid-40s to mid-60s degrees Fahrenheit, which is pleasant for walking around and sightseeing – just don’t forget to pack warm layers.

Stay at a historic hotel in the French Quarter

Hotel Monteleone

Our rideshare navigated the bustling roadways of the city as I admired the sights and sounds from the car window. The driver dropped us off in front of the Hotel Monteleone.

Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement

I’m a fan of the paranormal and had heard that this hotel was one of the most haunted places in the US, so that is why I booked our stay here. Before you keep reading, I know what you’re thinking – how romantic of me. I didn’t tell my husband this spooky detail in advance. I just told him it was a beautiful historic hotel. For the record, nothing ghostly happened during our stay.

We walked inside and were immediately in awe of the dazzling Christmas lights. The lobby was magnificently decorated. We checked in, dropped our luggage off in our room, freshened up, and put on our dinner outfits. We went downstairs to try and grab a seat at the famous Carousel Bar. This bar rotates like a carousel and is an iconic city attraction.

Sadly, the bar was packed, so we didn’t have a cocktail there. Instead, we headed out on the town to see more Christmas lights before dinner.

Top spots to see holiday sparkles

We walked over to the Roosevelt to see the holiday lights and grab a cocktail. It was incredible. Then we returned to the Hotel Monteleone for dinner at the Criollo Restaurant. Criollo was one of our favorite places to eat during this trip. We treated ourselves to their Réveillon multi-course holiday meal.

In December, the Hotel Monteleone, the Roosevelt Hotel, the Windsor Court, the Royal Sonesta, the Ritz Carlton, the Bourbon Orleans, and La Pavillon all spectacularly decorate their lobbies for Christmas.

Gorge on beignets and explore the French Quarter

St. Louis Cathedral New Orleans

We’d heard Café du Monde was the best breakfast place, so we kicked our second day off walking there. My husband ordered the famous beignets, and I grabbed a coffee. He wholeheartedly enjoyed their fluffy beignets covered in powdered sugar.

Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement

Café du Monde is across the street from Jackson Square. You can walk over there and see the St. Louis Cathedral.

Afterward, we wandered around Woldenberg Riverfront Park. It was a cloudy and misty day when we visited, but I loved exploring the square and seeing the Mississippi River along the riverfront park.

Get lost roaming around Bourbon Street

New Orleans French Quarter

I’ve always been interested in magic, so we headed towards Bourbon Street to visit the Voodoo Museum. It is located between Bourbon and Royal Street. The museum was darker than expected, but I found it fascinating.

There are more Voodoo shops in the area, too. Yes, I bought a Voodoo doll (also called a Gris Gris doll), and contrary to what I have seen on TV, they can bring good luck and protection — depending on the magic spell.

When you’re hungry from walking around town and window shopping, have lunch at Maspero's. It’s known for its authentic NOLA vibes and is an affordable spot to grab a bite.

Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement

We wrapped up the day enjoying dinner at Brennan’s. I was tickled when I saw their building was pink. This upscale restaurant is famous for its Creole food, and December is one of the best times to eat here – they serve Réveillon specials (at least they did the year we visited). If you didn’t make early reservations, see if your hotel concierge can help.

Have a transformative psychic reading

New Orleans bridge

I had always wanted to do a psychic reading, and I knew New Orleans was famous for this kind of activity. So I Googled “the best psychics in New Orleans,” and Cari Roy popped up . I emailed to make an appointment.

On the third day of our trip, her assistant miraculously managed to squeeze me into the schedule at the last minute (Cari Roy books months in advance). I was ecstatic.

Psychic readings are very personal, and Cari Roy was welcoming, kind, and surprisingly spot-on. I’ll never forget the experience. It was enlightening.

Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement

After the reading, we grabbed dinner at Gallier’s Restaurant and Oyster Bar . It’s just down the street from Cari Roy’s office. High on life after my first psychic reading, we splurged on Rockefeller oysters and sparkling wine. The oysters were amazing.

Step into the soul of New Orleans

The Spotted Cat Club

On our last night, we caught a taxi to Frenchmen Street to visit a few jazz clubs. Some of the bars required covers, and others did not. We were on a mission to check out the Spotted Cat before calling it a night. It’s one of the most famous jazz clubs in the city.

Other things to do while visiting

Canal Street streetcar

If you have more time to spend in New Orleans, or if this is your second or third trip here, people love going on ghost tours , seeing the famous cemeteries, and visiting the National WWII Museum .

You can also shop on Royal Street, look for antiques on Magazine Street, or take the streetcar .

body.title: Scientists make major Mars discovery from meteorite that's 4.5 billion years old
body.description: Scientists have figured out a key part of Mars' history after examining a meteorite believed to date back 4.5 billion years.
body.article_content:
Scientists have figured out a key part of Mars' history after examining a meteorite believed to date back 4.5 billion years.

The chunk of space rock, which was pinged in to space after a huge impact on the surface of Mars, landed on Earth's Sahara desert a good while ago.

Dubbed 'Black Beauty' by scientific experts examining the object - a name given to it as a result of its smooth black surface - the multi-billion-year-old rock was first discovered back in 2011 after being dug up in Morocco.

Advert

Found by nomads in the desert, it was bought by a meteorite dealer (yes, they are a real thing) before segments were donated for research.

Mars didn't always look so barren (Getty Stock Image)

Now officially called Northwest Africa 7034, scientists have been analysing the meteorite for the last 13 years.

And now, Aaron Cavosie and his team at Curtin University in Australia, have made a discovery about the rock that has changed how we think about Mars.

Advert

"It’s a wonderful buffet of Martian history, a mixture of very old and very young rocks," he said.

"But many of the fragments in it are among the oldest pieces of rock from Mars."

The stunning 'Black Beauty' meteorite (University of New Mexico)

The piece that was analysed by Cavosie and company had been crystallised in magma far below the surface of Mars.

Advert

In that piece, they found elements iron, aluminium and sodium. And the weird thing about them? They were arranged in thin, uniform layers.

What does this mean? Well, it hints at what Mars was once like before being a desolate rock with very little atmosphere.

Instead, it shows us that hot water was once present on the planet.

"We wondered, where else do you find elements like this," Carvosie explained.

Advert

Hot water on Mars was once a thing, the research suggests (Getty Stock Image)

"These kinds of zircons are only known to form where hydrothermal processes, hot water systems, are active during magmatism.

"The hot water facilitates transportation of the iron, aluminium and sodium into the crystal as it grows, layer by layer."

Back on Earth, these elemental layers are present in places such as gold ore deposits - with the comparison almost identical to the Martian object.

Advert

Eva Scheller, of Stanford University, added that it indicated a time in Martian history where water vapour had been released into Mars' atmosphere before the formation of rivers and lakes on the planet.

“At such an ancient age of 4.5 billion years, we are placed at the timing of when Mars formed,” Scheller said.

“So this would mark evidence of some of the earliest behaviour of water on Mars.”

body.title: Earth’s "evil twin" Venus was never habitable; new study confirms
body.description: New research suggests Venus, Earth's "evil twin," never had liquid water, challenging previous theories about its potential ...
body.article_content:
Image source: ESA

Venus, Earth’s evil twin, provides new insights

Venus's dry volcanic activity suggests it never had oceans, challenging habitability theories

Venus discovery reshapes exoplanet search

New research supports "born hot" theory, ruling out Venus

Venus discovery reshapes exoplanet search, highlighting key clues for finding habitable planets

Also Read |

Scientists have long debated whether Venus , often dubbed Earth ’s "evil twin," could have once supported life. However, new research is casting serious doubt on this theory, suggesting that the planet’s surface never hosted the essential ingredient for life—liquid water.This ground-breaking study, published in Nature Astronomy, comes from a team of researchers at the University of Cambridge. By analysing Venus’s atmospheric chemistry and volcanic gases, the team concluded that Venus’s interior is far too dry to have ever supplied enough water to form oceans, dismissing the idea that the planet could have once harboured life.The latest research into Venus’s atmosphere and volcanic gases has shattered the long-standing theory that the planet could have once supported life. With Venus’s surface likely never having hosted liquid water, the search for life in our solar system and beyond is being refocused on planets that are more Earth-like in their composition and environmental conditions. As we await further findings from future missions like NASA ’s DAVINCI, this new understanding of Venus challenges our notions of what makes a planet habitable and urges us to look elsewhere in the universe for signs of life.Today, Venus is a hellish world characterised by surface temperatures reaching around 1,000°F (500°C), which is hot enough to melt lead. The planet’s atmosphere is composed of clouds of sulfuric acid, creating a nearly impossible environment for life as we know it. For years, scientists speculated that Venus might have been cooler billions of years ago, possibly allowing for liquid water to exist on its surface. However, the latest research challenges this idea, suggesting that Venus was “born hot” and may have never had the conditions required for water to exist in a liquid state.This research holds particular significance, not just for understanding Venus’s past, but also for the study of exoplanets—planets orbiting stars beyond our solar system. If Venus was never habitable, it could imply that Venus-like planets elsewhere in the universe are also less likely to support life.The Cambridge research team, led by PhD student Tereza Constantinou, examined Venus’s atmospheric chemistry, particularly the destruction of key chemicals like water vapor, carbon dioxide, and carbonyl sulfide. They found that the lack of water vapor in Venus's volcanic eruptions was a crucial clue. On Earth, volcanic eruptions release a significant amount of water vapor due to our water-rich interior. However, Venus's volcanic gases contain no more than 6% water vapor, suggesting the planet’s interior has never been wet enough to support oceans.This dry volcanic activity led the researchers to conclude that Venus's surface was never able to hold enough water to form oceans, a key requirement for life to thrive.The discovery has profound implications for the search for life beyond our solar system. Exoplanets, or planets that orbit other stars, come in many varieties, some of which are similar in size and temperature to Venus. If Venus was never habitable, it suggests that planets like Venus might not be ideal candidates for harbouring life, either.The research could also help refine our understanding of how planets evolve and where we should focus our search for life elsewhere in the universe. While scientists are eagerly awaiting NASA's upcoming DAVINCI mission, set to launch in 2029, which will send a probe to Venus to gather more data, this new finding already points to a need to focus on planets that are more likely to have liquid water, such as Earth-like exoplanets in the habitable zone.There are two primary theories about Venus’s past and how it may have evolved. The first theory suggests that Venus could have once been cool enough to harbor liquid water. Over time, volcanic activity and a runaway greenhouse effect could have gradually raised the planet’s temperature to the extreme levels we see today.The second theory, which the new research supports, proposes that Venus was "born hot" and never had the necessary conditions to sustain liquid water. This theory suggests that Venus was always a hostile world, incapable of supporting life, even in its distant past.Constantinou explains that the team’s research is based on current observations of Venus’s atmosphere, rather than relying solely on climate models. They looked at how quickly water and other chemicals are removed from the atmosphere and replenished by volcanic eruptions. This allowed them to infer that Venus’s interior, unlike Earth’s, has always been too dry to have ever hosted oceans.While this new revelation may disappoint those hoping that Venus once supported life, it serves as a valuable lesson for astronomers in the search for habitable planets. If Venus, despite its Earth-like size and proximity to the Sun, was never habitable, then scientists may need to focus their efforts on finding exoplanets with conditions more similar to Earth’s.Constantinou notes, "Even though it’s the closest planet to us, Venus is important for exoplanet science because it gives us a unique opportunity to explore a planet that evolved very differently to ours, right at the edge of the habitable zone." The discovery also highlights the need to be more selective in the search for life, with astronomers now considering factors such as volcanic activity and atmospheric chemistry as important clues in identifying planets that could support life.The discovery of Venus’s inhospitable past does not mark the end of exploration, however. NASA's DAVINCI mission, which is expected to launch in June 2029, will provide new insights into Venus's atmosphere and surface conditions. The mission will send a probe into the planet's thick atmosphere, collecting vital data that could help answer the ultimate question: Could Venus have ever supported life?While the probe is not designed to survive the harsh conditions on Venus’s surface, it may provide a fleeting glimpse of the planet’s surface, adding more pieces to the puzzle of Venus’s past.

body.title: Holiday Music and Light Show puts downtown Florence in new light. When does it start?
body.description: Christmas brings its magic to downtown Florence on Dec. 6 with a Christmas tree lighting ceremony, Downtown Christmas Magic ...
body.article_content:
FLORENCE — Three unusual reindeer and a unique penguin are joining the magic of Christmas in downtown Florence this year.

The decorations are part of the Downtown Florence Music and Light Show in the 100 block of South Dargan Street. The Holiday Music and Light Show is starting its ninth year as a downtown attraction.

City of Florence public works employees were putting the Christmas tree up in the Andrew H. Griffin Plaza on Dec. 3.

Downtown Christmas Magic will come to life at 5:30 p.m. Dec. with the 31st annual City-County Christmas Tree Lighting.

A special Tuba Christmas performance of Christmas carols will help jump start the lighting ceremony.

Once it's complete, Downtown Christmas Magic will get underway as will the Holiday Music and Light Show, sponsored by Duke Energy.

The night is a big present of holiday cheer for the Florence community.

"Immediately following the lights coming on on the big Christmas tree, we will immediately transition into Downtown Christmas Magic," Florence Downtown Development Manager Hannah Davis said. "We have some amazing stuff happening during that event this year. It runs from 5:30 p.m. to 9 p.m."

Snowzilla, a 35-foot tall snow slide, is back. Roller Sledding will make its first appearance at Downtown Christmas Magic, Davis said. Roller Sledding is a toboggan tunnel.

Other attractions, including crafts, will help adults and children have a fun start to the holiday season, Davis said.

"We have three special guest coming this year," Davis said. "We have Santa Claus from 6-8:30 p.m. He will be over at the Christmas tree in the Griffin Plaza. Then in the James Allen Plaza from time-to-time you will also see his buddy Rudolph. Then, the Grinch comes to close everything out for us."

body.title: Future-Proofing For 2025: Emerging Tech Trends For Business Leaders
body.description: Here are three tech trends set to reshape industries, each with unique implications for business leaders aiming to strengthen ...

body.title: Top 5 Cyber Security Trends for 2025
body.description: TechRepublic asked cyber experts to predict the top trends that will impact the security field in 2025. The cyber landscape ...
body.article_content:
The cyber landscape is more turbulent than ever. Microsoft recently reported a 2.75-fold increase in ransomware attempts this year, while research predicts that global cyber attacks in 2024 will surge 105% compared to 2020.

There is a dire need for more qualified cyber professionals as generative AI is lowering the barrier to entry for attacks. Unfortunately, cyber skills gaps have been reported in both the U.K. and Australia, with women making up only a quarter of the industry.

But how will we roll into next year? TechRepublic asked cyber experts to predict the top trends impacting the security field in 2025.

SEE: Number of Active Ransomware Groups Highest on Record

1. Renewed focus on third-party risk management, including the AI software supply chain

This year, headlines were dominated by the CrowdStrike incident, which disabled about 8.5 million Windows devices worldwide and caused huge disruption to emergency services, airports, law enforcement, and other critical organisations.

SEE: What is CrowdStrike? Everything You Need to Know

However, this is far from the first instance of a supply chain attack being put on the public’s radar; the MOVEit attacks from last year may also still be fresh in the mind. Due to the prevalence of these incidents, Forrester analysts predict that governments will ban certain third-party software in 2025.

Additionally, more companies are using Generative AI to code new software, which could open it up to weaknesses. AI-generated code has been known to cause outages, and security leaders are even considering banning the use of technology in software development.

For executives, this all illustrates how essential third-party risk management is to operations, leading to a new focus in 2025.

Max Shier, the chief information security officer at cyber advisory firm Optiv, told TechRepublic in an email: “Third party risk management, supply chain risk management, and increased oversight and regulatory requirements will drive the need for companies to focus on and mature their governance, risk, and compliance programs.”

Jacob Kalvo, the CEO of proxy provider Live Proxies, added: “It is expected that in 2025, organisations will likely shift toward proactive ways of assessing and monitoring supply chains. It could be leveraging zero-trust architectures that will verify at stages of access, where the companies deal with external partners.

“This shift to increased supply chain scrutiny marks a wider trend of bringing cybersecurity into general enterprise-wide risk management.”

AI software is one of the weakest links in the software supply chain

While businesses race to capitalise on generative AI solutions, the speed of their adoption has resulted in some areas of oversight when it comes to security. A study from HackerOne found that 48% of security professionals believe AI poses the most significant security risk to their organisation.

Cache Merrill, founder of software development company Zibtek, told TechRepublic by email: “As AI tools increasingly integrate into software development, we anticipate attackers targeting the software supply chain’s weakest AI-driven components. The focus will no longer be just on vetting third-party code but scrutinising AI models that may have inadvertently introduced security gaps through data poisoning or bias exploitation.

“By 2025, supply chain security will demand a whole new layer of vigilance, where even the datasets and AI models feeding into our applications are analysed for adversarial tampering. A secure supply chain won’t just be about code but curating safe and verifiable AI training sources.”

Paul Caiazzo, VP of security services at Quorum Cyber, told TechRepublic that attackers may specifically target weaker AI tools to exfiltrate sensitive data. “CISOs will struggle to secure them due to a lack of AI skills and tooling,” he added.

2. Macs will become more targeted by cybercriminals

Experts say that Macs will become even more of a target for cybercriminals in the next year. Kseniia Yamburh, malware research engineer at Moonlock, the security division of MacPaw, told TechRepublic by email: “Once considered safer, macOS now faces rising threats, particularly from stealer malware designed to collect sensitive data.

“Our research at Moonlock shows a notable spike in macOS-targeted stealer malware, with 2024 seeing 3.4 times more unique samples than 2023.”

SEE: Threat Actors Increasingly Target macOS, Report Finds

The number of macOS vulnerabilities exploited in 2023 increased by more than 30%, with attackers using infostealers, fake PDFs, fake Mac apps, legitimate Microsoft apps, and other novel techniques to breach the operating system this year. In November, several malicious macOS apps were linked to North Korea.

The growing interest in Apple devices may be due to their increasing prevalence in organisations and greater competition amongst cybercriminals in the Windows landscape.

3. Identity to shift into the jurisdiction of security teams

Security experts predict that in 2025, responsibility for identity and access management within companies will shift from IT departments to security teams. Sagie Dulce, VP of research at segmentation firm Zero Networks, said identity-based attacks are the leading cause of breaches, and this is not looking to change. As these attacks escalate, security professionals are needed to eliminate potential entry points.

Dulce told TechRepublic: “This is not new, but is a growing trend as more identities belong to services and apps — they are harder to manage and control. Most organisations are currently blind to their exposure from service accounts, privileged identities, secrets spread, third party access, and more.

“These identities are often the lowest-hanging fruits in organisations and attackers know it. As many web applications are still exposed to the internet, getting initial access via compromised credentials to a web app remains the main attack vector utilised to gain initial access.”

4. Cyber regulations will divide countries

Global cyber regulations are becoming stricter — especially with the rise in nation-state cyber attacks. As a result, legislation will focus on geopolitics and national security interests.

Vishal Gupta, CEO of security software provider Seclore, told TechRepublic in an email: “In the coming year, long raging wars and general geopolitical tensions will drive the bulk of regulations. Countries and groups of countries will create regulations to protect their own interests over deemed enemies and will prevent the broad spread of supply chains.

“This is already evident in the CHIPS act and more recent [export control law] interpretations. ‘Country over collaboration’ may well be the theme of these regulations.”

Douglas McKee, executive director of Threat Research at security firm SonicWall, added that it will become increasingly difficult to detect the origins of attacks because “the line between state and criminal operations will continue to blur further.”

SEE: Tenable: Cyber Security Pros Should Worry About State-Sponsored Cyber Attacks

As a result, decision-makers should strengthen international collaboration rather than create more division. McKee told TechRepublic in an email: “Governments and private organisations must adapt to this evolving threat landscape, focusing more on proactive intelligence sharing and threat-hunting to disrupt collaborative efforts before they impact critical sectors.”

Critical national infrastructure will fall behind in compliance

Critical national infrastructure, such as transport, telecommunications companies, and data centres, is a key target for attackers because it can lead to widespread disruption. A recent report from Malwarebytes found that the services industry is the worst affected by ransomware, accounting for almost a quarter of global attacks.

SEE: 80% of Critical National Infrastructure Companies Experienced an Email Security Breach in Last Year

According to Christian Borst, EMEA CTO at security firm Vectra AI, attacks on CNI will surge in 2025, partly because these firms are not keeping up with regulations. These include NIS2, which aims to establish a consistent, minimum cybersecurity baseline across all E.U. member states.

Borst told TechRepublic in an email: “Regulators aren’t asking the world, but CNI firms are already struggling to stick to the timelines set out by regulators and get their houses in order, as we’re already seeing E.U. member states who are lagging behind on NIS2 implementation.

“Threat actors will be well aware of lagging compliance, so will concentrate efforts on targeting critical infrastructure before the security gaps are closed.”

5. Specific employees targeted via social media and AI

At the start of the year, a finance worker in Hong Kong paid out $25 million to hackers that used AI and publicly available video content to impersonate the chief financial officer. The hackers mimicked the executive’s voice during phone calls to authorise the transfer.

Experts predict that this behaviour will continue into 2025. According to Garner, AI-enhanced malicious attacks were the top emerging business risk throughout the year’s first three quarters.

The number of business email compromise attacks detected by security firm Vipre in the second quarter was 20% higher than the same period in 2023, and two-fifths of them were generated by AI. The top targets were CEOs, followed by HR and IT personnel.

Darius Belejevas, head of data privacy platform Incogni, told TechRepublic: “An ever-increasing number of data breaches are now the result of criminals actively targeting specific employees, in some cases armed with personal information they have managed to source on that individual. Unfortunately not enough people realise they are being targeted because of where they work.”
